overview: Information about the welfare of horses on farms and livery yards and how to dispose of waste and fallen stock
title: Farm and livery horses

table.body:
A horse is considered to be an agricultural animal if it is used to farm agricultural land or is farmed for meat or hides.

Horses on farms or in stables and livery yards are protected by the [Animal Welfare Act.](http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2006/45/contents "Animal Welfare Act"){:rel="external"} If you own or are responsible for a horse, you have a duty to look after its basic welfare by:

* providing it with a suitable place to live
* giving it a suitable diet
* protecting it from pain, injury, suffering and disease
* making sure it can behave normally and naturally

%You can be fined up to £20,000 or sent to prison for up to 6 months if you are cruel to an animal or don’t care for it properly. You may also be banned from owning animals in future.%

The standards for looking after horses on farms or in livery yards are set out in the Department for Environment Food and Rural Affairs (Defra) 'Code of Practice for the Welfare of Horses, Ponies, Donkeys and their Hybrids'. 

$D
[Download 'Code of Practice for the Welfare of Horses, Ponies, Donkeys and their Hybrids' (PDF, 580KB)](http://adlib.everysite.co.uk/resources/000/263/388/PB13334.pdf "Download 'Code of Practice for the Welfare of Horses, Ponies, Donkeys and their Hybrids' (PDF, 580KB)"){:rel="external"}
$D

Failing to follow the Code of Practice could be used against you if you are prosecuted under the Animal Welfare Act.

*[Defra]: Department for Environment Food and Rural Affairs
table.title: Looking after horses

table.body:
At a livery yard, horses are housed and cared for in return for payment but don't belong to the owner of the yard. 

Health and safety standards for livery yards are set out by the Chartered Institute for Environmental Health.

$D
[Download 'Health and safety guidance for inspections of horse riding establishments and livery yards' (PDF, 1.52MB)](http://adlib.everysite.co.uk/resources/000/264/078/Livery_Yards_Guidance_2006.pdf "Download 'Livery yards health and safety guidance' (PDF, 1.52MB)"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Planning permission for stables and livery yards

Stables and livery yards require [planning permission](/planning-permission/overview "Planning permission") from your local planning authority. 

You can [make a planning application online.](http://www.planningportal.gov.uk/planning/applications/planningapplications "Make a planning application"){:rel="external"}
table.title: Stables and livery yards

table.body:
##Horse manure
Horse manure is not considered waste if all of the following apply:

* it is used as soil fertiliser
* it is used lawfully for spreading on clearly identified pieces of agricultural land
* it is only stored to be used for spreading on agricultural land

If you store or spread horse waste near to water, it can be a health hazard and could harm the environment. You will need to follow rules on [Nitrate Vulnerable Zones](http://www.environment-agency.gov.uk/business/sectors/54714.aspx "Nitrate Vulnerable Zones"){:rel="external"} and follow [rules on the pollution of groundwater.](http://www.environment-agency.gov.uk/business/regulation/31881.aspx "groundwater directives"){:rel="external"}


##Getting rid of solid waste

Solid waste includes things like:

* contaminated bedding
* food containers
* horse manure (if not used as soil fertiliser)
* empty pesticide and other chemical containers
* plastics such as silage wrap, bags and sheets
* tyres, batteries, clinical waste, old machinery and oil

%You must use a licensed facility to get rid of solid waste - it’s against the law to dump or burn it.%

Contact the Environment Agency or your local authority for information on how to get rid of solid waste.

$C
**Environment Agency helpline**  
03708 506 506
$C 

Some biodegradable waste can be composted. [Composting plants](http://www.environment-agency.gov.uk/business/topics/permitting/34785.aspx "composting plants"){:rel="external"} must be registered with the Environment Agency. You may need an [environmental permit](http://www.environment-agency.gov.uk/business/topics/permitting/default.aspx "environmental permits"){:rel="external"} for on-site composting of some materials.
table.title: Dealing with waste
Transporting horses

table.body:
If you think that a horse has a [notifiable disease](http://animalhealth.defra.gov.uk/managing-disease/notifiable-disease/index.htm "notifiable disease"){:rel="external"} then you must immediately contact your [local Animal Health Office.](http://animalhealth.defra.gov.uk/about/contact-us/postcode.asp "find your local Animal Health Office"){:rel="external"}


##Fallen stock

If a horse dies or has to be put down on your premises, you will have to arrange its disposal as fallen stock under [animal by-products (ABPs) controls.](http://www.defra.gov.uk/food-farm/byproducts/ "animal by-products controls"){:rel="external"}

This includes:

* entire animal bodies
* parts of animals
* products of animal origin
* other products obtained from animals that are not for human consumption. 

You must deal with ABPs promptly to protect people, animals and the environment. In most cases, this will mean arranging for them to be taken away to approved premises, like:

* rendering plants
* incinerators
* collection centres
* storage plants

Your local council can provide a list of approved premises for the disposal of ABPs. 

The [National Fallen Stock Scheme](http://www.nfsco.co.uk/ "National Fallen Stock Scheme"){:rel="external"} is a not-for-profit scheme which helps farmers and animal owners to follow the law on disposing of fallen stock. 

$C**National Fallen Stock Scheme helpline**    
0845 054 8888$C


*[ABPs]: Animals by-products
